channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Markets Saying Fed Rate Cut Premature: JPM's Herr
item.description: Kay Herr, US CIO for Global Fixed Income, Currencies and Commodities at JPMorgan Asset Management, says markets are indicating a Fed rate cut is premature and sees a lot of noise in economic data. She speaks to Bloomberg's Sonali Basak on 'Real Yield.' (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Is Tesla More About Elon Musk Than the Cars?
item.description: Charles Lemonides, the CIO and Founder of Valueworks--an investment firm that holds names like Rivian, joined Wall Street Beat on Blooomberg Open Interest to talk about why gamblers should bet on Tesla, and those who want the best electric vehicle positioning should look elsewhere. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Carney to Fast-Track ‘Nation-Building’ Projects Through Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.
item.dc:creator: Laura Dhillon Kane

item.title: S&P 500 Gains as Jobs Report Fuels Slide in Bonds: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks headed toward their highest since February and bond yields rose as US jobs data allayed concerns of an imminent economic slowdown, steadying Wall Street in the aftermath of President Donald Trump’s market-moving war of words with Elon Musk.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth, Andre Janse Van Vuuren

item.title: Infiniti Starts Production of Qx60 in the US
item.description: Nissan’s luxury brand Infiniti recently revamped its full-size SUV offering for the first time in 14 years and has begun producing the QX60 in the U.S. We spoke with Tiago Castro, Infiniti Group Vice President, about the move from a plant in Tennessee. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Senators Ask Housing Finance Agency to Pause Plans to Privatize Fannie, Freddie
item.description: A group of Democratic senators, including Elizabeth Warren and Chuck Schumer, asked the director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency to pause any efforts to privatize mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: The Freddie Mac headquarters in Mclean, Virginia, US, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. The head of the US Federal Housing Finance Agency on Tuesday ordered to end Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac programs intended to support first-time homebuyers by providing down payments and closing cost assistance.

item.title: Creating the New Economy: The Investors' View
item.description: Paul Eitelman, Global Chief Investment Strategist, Russell Investments, Leigh Marie Braswell, Partner, Kleiner Perkins, and Vibhor Rastogi, Global Head of AI Investment, Citi Ventures, share forward-looking sector strategies, breakthrough innovations, and approaches to navigating regulatory change with Bloomberg’s Diksha Gera at The Future Investor: Finding the Opportunities event in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: America’s Data Disaster Is Already Here
item.description: This is what economists were worried about.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: "We're Hiring" pamphlets on a table during a job fair hosted by the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority to support federal workers looking for new career opportunities, at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport (DCA) in Arlington, Virginia, US, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The US Bureau of Labor Statistics is scheduled to release unemployment rate figures on May 2. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Tesla Stock Recovers as Musk Feud With Trump Eases
item.description: Tesla's shares rose after Elon Musk suggested he might make amends with President Donald Trump, easing tensions after their public feud. Musk said on X that he should “cool off and take a step back for a couple days.” Craig Trudell reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Revelation-Backed Omada Health Jumps After $150 Million IPO
item.description: Omada Health Inc. shares climbed 21% in their trading debut after the digital health-care company raised $150 million in its initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: Angel Adegbesan, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: A Wall Street sign near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 22, 2025. A surge in long-term bond yields is once again threatening to upend a crowded hedge-fund bet that Treasuries will perform better than interest-rate swaps. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: What Next for UBS After Swiss Lay Out Capital Demand?
item.description: After more than a year of waiting, UBS Group AG finally has a clearer idea of how much money it will need to find if Switzerland forces the bank to take on more capital to deal with future crises. Now comes the effort to soften the hit.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Noele Illien

media:content.media:description: A UBS Group AG bank branch in Zurich. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

item.title: Dan Ives’ Fund Launched Just in Time for Elon Musk’s Meltdown
item.description: Ives is still sticking by his bull case for Tesla
item.dc:creator: Katie Greifeld

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico

item.title: Colombia Assets Drop on Reports Fiscal Rule May Be Suspended
item.description: Colombia’s bonds and currency sold off on Friday amid investor fears that the government may suspend the fiscal anchor that curbs its ability to run up debt.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song

item.title: UBS Faces $26 Billion Capital Demand From Swiss Bank Reforms
item.description: UBS Group AG is facing as much as $26 billion in fresh capital requirements to be phased in over the next decade under banking reform proposals from the Swiss government.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Noele Illien

media:content.media:description: The UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

item.title: Power CEO Says US to Lose AI Race to China Without New Lines
item.description: The question of whether or not the US wins the race with China to develop artificial intelligence will hinge on Washington backing the construction of power superhighways to move large quantities of electricity, according to one of the country’s biggest energy developers.
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik, Mark Chediak

media:content.media:description: Co-founder and CEO of Invenergy LLC Michael Polsky

item.title: Yale’s $2.5 Billion Private Equity Sale Tests Its Vaunted Endowment Model
item.description: Yale University’s $41 billion endowment, led for decades by the late investing giant David Swensen, has been the envy – and the blueprint — for many US universities eager to secure their financial future.
item.dc:creator: Allison McNeely, Dawn Lim, Preeti Singh, Marion Halftermeyer

media:content.media:description: The Yale University campus in New Haven, Connecticut, US, on Tuesday, April 23, 2024. Campuses across the US have been grappling with pro-Palestinian protests and counter demonstrations since the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas.

item.title: US Labor Secretary on May Jobs Report, Immigration
item.description: US Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer reacts to the May report that shows the US added 139,000 new jobs, topping estimates. She says the Trump administration is focused on growing the workforce and says "native born Americans" are getting more jobs. She speaks to Bloomberg's Annmarie Hordern. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: African Panel Challenges Fitch’s Afreximbank Ratings Downgrade
item.description: An African Union-backed panel challenged Fitch Ratings to review its downgrade of the African Export-Import Bank’s rating, questioning the company’s classification of loans to three countries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Benedict Okey Oramah, President and Chairman of the Board of Directors for Afreximbank.

item.title: Rosenberg Sees a 'Slowing-But-Still Strong Labor Market'
item.description: Jeffrey Rosenberg, portfolio manager at BlackRock Inc., says the May jobs report means the Federal Reserve can take a wait-and-see approach when it comes to interest rates. “The big takeaway is a slowing-but-still strong labor market," he said on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Labor Market Looks Fragile, Fed Won’t Cut: KPMG’s Swonk
item.description: KPMG Chief Economist Diane Swonk says the May jobs numbers “had a soft underbelly to them that is getting lost in translation.” Speaking on “Bloomberg Open Interest.” Swonk also says the Federal Reserve won’t cut interest rates in the wake of the employment report.

item.title: BNP to Cut 200 French Branches by 2027 to Kick Off Retail Revamp
item.description: BNP Paribas SA Chief Executive Officer Jean-Laurent Bonnafe plans to cut hundreds of domestic retail branches in an effort to lift profitability at a business that has struggled for years.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen

media:content.media:description: A BNP Paribas bank branch in Paris.

item.title: Gold’s Cheaper Precious-Metal Peers Surge to Multi-Year Highs
item.description: Silver extended gains to 13-year highs and platinum reached the highest since early 2022, signaling growing investor appetite for precious metals used in key industries.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

item.title: Oil Rises as Solid US Jobs Data Pushes Algos to Drop Short Bets
item.description: Oil rose as stronger-than-expected US jobs data eased concerns that an economic slowdown will crimp demand, spurring algorithmic traders to reduce short positions.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: A pump jack in Midland, Texas. Photographer: Anthony Prieto/Bloomberg

item.title: B. Riley Financial Wins Nasdaq Extension to Head Off Delisting
item.description: B. Riley Financial Inc., still struggling to produce its overdue financial reports, won an extension from Nasdaq to keep trading on the exchange till the end of the third quarter.
item.dc:creator: Yizhu Wang

media:content.media:description: B. Riley Financial offices in Westlake Village, California, US, on Thursday, Nov. 7, 2024. B. Riley Financial is selling assets to raise cash to cut its own debt load, and while the investment firm remains long overdue on filing its financial results for the second quarter.

item.title: Trump Is Holding Back From Calling Out China Over Russia War Aid
item.description: President Donald Trump is holding back from pushing China to halt support for Russia’s war machine as he focuses on other issues in the relationship with its biggest geopolitical rival, according to US and European officials familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a meeting with Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Relations between Washington and Berlin are tense amid issues ranging from trade imbalances to support for Kyiv.

item.title: Asset Managers Jump Back Into Brazil’s Battered Stock Market
item.description: Asset managers in Brazil are ramping up to take full advantage of a comeback in local equities after long stretches of weak performance pushed investors to flee.
item.dc:creator: Leda Alvim, Barbara Nascimento, Felipe Saturnino

media:content.media:description: The financial district in downtown Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, Sept. 19, 2024. Brazil's central bank raised its interest rate by a quarter-point and said more hikes are coming on resilient growth and inflation expectations, moving in the opposite direction of the Federal Reserve and regional peers.

item.title: Traders Reel In Fed Cut Bets as Strong Job Data Drags on Bonds
item.description: Treasuries slumped after stronger-than-expected US job and wage growth prompted traders to trim bets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates this year.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Michael Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Rent the Runway’s Comeback Plan
item.description: Rent The Runway's subscriber base is growing as the fashion rental company reworks its business model by offering more brands and debuting a new rewards program. Jennifer Hyman, CEO of Rent The Runway joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the revamp. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed Will ‘Sit on Hands’ After May Jobs Report: Rieder
item.description: Rick Rieder, BlackRock CIO of global fixed income, reacts to the May employment report and discusses what it could mean for Federal Reserve monetary policy on “Bloomberg Open Interest.” Nonfarm payrolls increased 139,000 last month after a combined 95,000 in downward revisions to the prior two months, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data.

item.title: JPMorgan U-Turns on Stock Market, Now Sees Slight Gain for 2025
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is the latest Wall Street firm to pull an about-face on the US stock market, raising its S&P 500 Index target as equities continue to climb despite ongoing uncertainty about President Donald Trump’s trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.
